author: Grimms
text: It happened that the cat met the fox in a forest, and as she thought to herself: "He is clever and full of experience, and much esteemed in the world," she spoke to him in a friendly way.

author: Grimms
text: "Good day, dear Mr Fox, how are you?

author: Grimms
text: How is all with you?

author: Grimms
text: How are you getting on in these hard times?"

author: Grimms
text: The fox, full of all kinds of arrogance, looked at the cat from head to foot, and for a long time did not know whether he would give any answer or not.

author: Grimms
text: At last he said: "Oh, you wretched beard-cleaner, you piebald fool, you hungry mouse-hunter, what can you be thinking of?

author: Grimms
text: Have you the cheek to ask how I am getting on?

author: Grimms
text: What have you learnt?

author: Grimms
text: How many arts do you understand?"

author: Grimms
text: "I understand but one," replied the cat, modestly.

author: Grimms
text: "What art is that?" asked the fox.

author: Grimms
text: "When the hounds are following me, I can spring into a tree and save myself."

author: Grimms
text: "Is that all?" said the fox.

author: Grimms
text: "I am master of a hundred arts, and have into the bargain a sackful of cunning.

author: Grimms
text: You make me sorry for you; come with me, I will teach you how people get away from the hounds."

author: Grimms
text: Just then came a hunter with four dogs.

author: Grimms
text: The cat sprang nimbly up a tree, and sat down at the top of it, where the branches and foliage quite concealed her.

author: Grimms
text: "Open your sack, Mr Fox, open your sack," cried the cat to him, but the dogs had already seized him, and were holding him fast.

author: Grimms
text: "Ah, Mr Fox," cried the cat.

author: Grimms
text: "You with your hundred arts are left in the lurch!

author: Grimms
text: Had you been able to climb like me, you would not have lost your life."
